event_description: Archival data from TESS show 3I/ATLAS was present and possibly active before its official discovery. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}
3I/ATLAS is in the closest range with Saturn (9.931 AU)
The ATLAS survey in Chile first reported the interstellar comet. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}
Hubble Space Telescope captured sharp images permitting nucleus size constraints. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}
Ground-based imagery shows a prominent jet pointing toward the Sun, indicating strong outgassing. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}
Gemini South Observatory obtains deep exposures of the tail and coma structure. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}
Brightness and tail length increase significantly as the comet approaches the Sun. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}
3I/ATLAS makes its closest pass to Mars, providing excellent observational geometry. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}
Comet continues accelerating into inner system
Comet reaches its closest approach to the Sun; inner solar system max activity. :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}
